repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Roads Rehabilitation and
            Maintenance, and Freetown Infrastructure Rehabilitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit downgrades the Implementation
            Completion Report (ICR) rating of satisfactory project
            outcomes to moderately satisfactory for both the Roads
            Rehabilitation and Maintenance (RRMP), and the Freetown
            Infrastructure Rehabilitation (FIRP) Projects; concurs on a
            likely sustainability for the RRMP, but downgrades the FIRP
            sustainability to unlikely; and, downgrades the RRMP
            institutional development impact to substantial, yet concurs
            with the FIRP modest rating, and with both satisfactory
            performance ratings by the Bank and Borrower. The experience
            of these two operations convey the following. Projects
            implemented in countries with an ongoing conflict, should be
            continually monitored to identify, and assess the conflict
            risk to the projects. First, under continuing high risk
            conditions, thus project implementation likely to prove
            counterproductive, by exposing the Bank and Borrower to
            compensation and other claims, the Bank might consider
            disengagement until the environment improves. Second, upon
            resuming project implementation following a substantial
            period of inactivity due to conflict, technical and
            financial audits should be carried out to reassess
            priorities for action, as well as, and any remedial measures
            needed to secure completed activities. Third, when a country
            is in, or emerging from conflict, the Bank may need to adopt
            a more flexible approach to borrower compliance with
            reform-related loan covenants. A realistic timeframe should
            be agreed when attempting to introduce unpopular reforms in
            the context of violence, and social instability.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Freetown Infrastructure
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though institutional development
            impacts were only modest. Lessons learned are addressed as
            follows. First, lessons for project preparation indicate
            that although the project was not featured in the Country
            Assistance Strategy (needing additional funding allocation
            from the International Development Association (IDA) because
            of the civil conflict, it was nonetheless successfully
            implemented given its relief type lending, where assistance
            from Bank staff, provided strong inputs, even in the absence
            of a sector development strategy. However, a project such as
            this one, designed as a quick relief operation, should
            include sufficient activities for the physical outputs, and
            address capacity issues to ensure sustainability;
            additionally, arrangements for the road fund should have
            been made under the project, with assistance to be
            undertaken from the private sector. Second, as for project
            implementation, recommendations suggest that sound
            accounting, and financial management systems should have
            been included, to avoid irreconcilable difficulties of
            project accounts. Third, as per a post conflict assistance,
            it is paramount to count on political stability, or to be
            able to minimize claims due to force majeure, the absence of
            which delayed the resumption of some project activities,
            which are still unsettled.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Freetown Infrastructure
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project involves urban upgrading,
            including the improvement of six selected community/slum
            areas by providing roads/footpaths and drainage, water
            supply, toilets and sanitary and solid waste disposal
            facilities.  These six city center markets provide water
            supply, toilet and ablution facilities. Garbage collection,
            disposal facilities, solid waste operations and repairs are
            being added to market building structures. The project
            rehabilitates and upgrades access roads to the project area,
            as well as, the improvement of the Government of Sierra
            Leone's (GVWC) water supply system and operations by
            reducing water leakage through a metering and connection
            program. The institutional capabilities of the Sierra Leone
            Roads Authority (SLRA) to manage and coordinate this project
            is being strengthened. Technical assistance and coordinated
            studies are in place to address longer-term issues of
            infrastructural development in Greater Freetown. Financial
            review of the Freetown City Council (FCC) and city traffic
            management is also necessary.
